noun.description: The mass or magnitude of something large.
examples: the sheer bulk of the bags

verb.description: Be or seem to be of great size or importance.
examples: territorial questions bulked large in diplomatic relations

verb.description: Treat (a product) so that its quantity appears greater than it in fact is.
examples: traders were bulking up their flour with chalk

phrases: buying tomatoes in bulk from a local farmer
These wines are then on promotion at the store for the month of July, and come with a case price for those wanting to buy in bulk.
Walls have been insulated using old newspapers and there is a gas - fired community heating system, allowing fuel to be bought in bulk at a reduced cost.
The secret lies in the fact that it buys in bulk from China, whose marble is virtually indistinguishable from that of Italy, and commands fabulous discounts.
But I buy everything I need in bulk, to make sure I don't ever run out
origin: Middle English: the senses cargo as a whole and heap, large quantity (the earliest recorded) are probably from Old Norse búlki cargo; other senses arose perhaps by alteration of obsolete bouk belly, body.
